definition: **noun / technical.** A metal stamper whose groove walls are polished to a mirror-like sheen to reduce surface noise during pressing. Developed in the late 1970s as pressing plants sought to improve vinyl playback quality during the format's commercial peak, mirror-finish stampers undergo additional electroplating and polishing stages beyond standard nickel stamper production. The ultra-smooth groove surfaces minimize the micro-roughness that causes ticks, pops, and background noise, resulting in pressings with dramatically lower noise floors—particularly noticeable during quiet passages and lead-in grooves. Audiophile labels like Mobile Fidelity Sound Lab and Analogue Productions adopted mirror-finish stampers as standard practice by the mid-1980s, marketing the technique as a premium feature. The process adds significant cost and production time, as stampers require careful handling to prevent scratching and can wear faster than conventional stampers, limiting run sizes to 1,000-1,500 copies versus 3,000+ for standard stampers. Modern reissue plants continue using mirror-finish techniques for high-end pressings, with collectors often willing to pay premium prices for the superior sonic clarity these stampers deliver.
etymology: Term emerged in late 1970s pressing industry literature, describing stampers polished to reflective mirror quality through enhanced electroplating processes.
